notes: First-generation Mazda3 replaces Protegé. Built on Ford C1 platform shared with Volvo S40 and Ford Focus. MazdaSpeed3 performance variant with turbocharged engine available 2007-2009. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda3 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation Mazda6 midsize sedan. Available in sedan, hatchback, and wagon body styles. MazdaSpeed6 performance variant with turbocharged AWD available 2006-2007. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda6 article, December 19, 2024 revision.
Second-generation Mazda6 introduced late in decade. Sedan body style only. Larger V6 engine available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda6 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation Protegé compact sedan. Replaced by Mazda3 for 2004 model year. Protegé5 hatchback variant available 2002-2003. MazdaSpeed Protegé turbocharged variant (170 hp) available 2003 only. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Familia article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation MPV minivan with car-based FWD platform. Seating for up to seven passengers. Discontinued in North America after 2006 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MPV article, December 19, 2024 revision.
Fifth-generation 626 midsize sedan. Final years before replacement by Mazda6. Sedan body style only in this generation. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Capella article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Luxury sedan with unique Miller-cycle supercharged V6 engine on S trim. Discontinued after 2002 model year. Difficulty modifier reflects Miller-cycle engine complexity and supercharger maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Millenia article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation MX-5 Miata with updated styling and improved rigidity. 6-speed manual transmission available from 2001. Lightweight rear-wheel-drive sports car. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation MX-5 Miata introduced for 2006 model year. Larger and more powerful than previous generations. Power retractable hardtop (PRHT) available from 2007. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Sports car with 1.3L Renesis twin-rotor Wankel rotary engine. Features unique freestyle doors (rear-hinged rear doors). Manual transmission models produce 238 hp (232 hp from 2009), automatic models 212 hp. High difficulty modifier reflects specialized rotary engine maintenance including apex seal replacement, oil consumption monitoring, and compression testing requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda RX-8 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation Tribute compact SUV based on Ford Escape/Mercury Mariner CD2 platform. Jointly developed with Ford. Available with four-cylinder or V6 engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Tribute article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation Tribute compact SUV based on Ford Escape/Mercury Mariner CD2 platform. Hybrid variant available with 2.5L Atkinson-cycle engine and electric motor (153 hp combined). Difficulty modifier reflects hybrid system complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Tribute article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Midsize crossover with sporty styling and turbocharged engine. Built on Ford CD3 platform. Naturally aspirated 2.5L engine added for 2010 model year. Difficulty modifier reflects turbo maintenance complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-7 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation CX-9 three-row crossover with V6 engine. Shares Ford CD3 platform with Ford Edge and Lincoln MKX. Largest Mazda crossover SUV. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-9 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation Mazda5 compact minivan with sliding rear doors. Six-passenger seating in three rows. Smaller alternative to traditional minivans. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fourth-generation B-Series compact pickup truck based on Ford Ranger platform. Available in regular cab and extended cab configurations. Discontinued after 2009 model year in North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda B series article, December 19, 2024 revision.
